question: Unfortunately, I would be of little assistance to the Junior Assistance League. Particularly if my purpose were to appear as an alumna who is gifted at public speaking. Thank you and if you ask again I shall scream?
answer: Why don't you ask your husband for some pointers? He's a pretty gifted public speaker, don't you think? You should get out once in a while. Accepting that invitation would be good for Franklin's career.

question: Mr. Howe, wouldn't you be more comfortable waiting for my husband outside?
answer: In the street, Mrs. Roosevelt?

question: Because they always seem more grateful to see me when I arrive. Have a lovely day, Babs.
answer: Should I expect you for dinner?

question: I have the Navy reception this evening. I'll be home quite late. Unless you've changed your mind about coming?
answer: Do you wish me to come?

question: Well... whatever you'd like.
answer: Thank you, no.

question: Very well then. Good day, Miss Mercer.
answer: At ten you've got a meeting with representatives from Pittsburgh Steel. Their bid on the ship building contract has already been turned in and is on your desk for approval.

question: What did I think of it?
answer: You had some problems with it.

question: I better read it. Steel workers tend to vote democratic. Next.
answer: Lunch with Secretary Daniels.

question: Must I?
answer: He's your boss.

question: Anything else?
answer: What if she'd said yes?

question: Who?
answer: People know. It's time to stop.

question: I can handle my own affairs, Louis.
answer: Not this one. This is Washington, D.C., not the Harvard Club. How can you be so cavalier?

question: I humbly accept your nomination for Vice-President! They say the best way to get rid of a man is to have him run for Vice- President. You might well have asked my cousin Teddy if that's how they got rid of him!
answer: Of course you lost. A Roosevelt on the democratic ticket? Our ancestors are turning in their graves.

question: Cousin Alice, if Teddy were alive he'd be a democrat -- and you know it.
answer: Rubbish. But I do know one thing

question: And what's wrong with that?
answer: Do you know what they're saying about you?

question: No, but I'm sure you'll tell me.
answer: They say F.D.R. stands for "featherduster." That you're a lightweight. A dilettante with no substance; no point of view.

question: Is that what you think?
answer: You lead with your vanity. You talk when you should listen. Unless these are the qualities of a democrat?

question: Darling, you're a Roosevelt. What do you know about people? Of course, I can think of one person you did manage to find the time to invest in. A Miss Mercer, I believe?
answer: Alice, stop.

question: Don't misunderstand me, Franklin. Being married to Eleanor I think you deserved some fun. But you made the right decision. Especially since Miss Mercer has gone on with her life.
answer: What are you talking about?

question: Edward Rutherford is a wonderful catch for a girl like her.
answer: She's married?

question: Last week. A small event, of course.
answer: When I last heard she was governess to his children.

question: We're not taking this defeat lying down, boss. We'll run you for Governor --
answer: Really? Of which state?

question: Very funny. No, this buys you time. It buys you experience.
answer: What about Al Smith?

question: He's vulnerable. You're still a fresh face, boss. We'll use that to our advantage.
answer: Boy Scouts, Louis? Hardly my political base.

question: They've got parents. Besides they're photogenic.
answer: Franklin Roosevelt, happy to meet you. Of course! What's your name, son? Guiseppe! Come sta, ragazzo?

question: Very well.
answer: Tired?

question: Of you? Never.
answer: Why don't you nap before dinner?

question: He can pursue a career, Mama.
answer: A man as proud and vital as Franklin... you're inviting him to be hurt.

question: Mama! That's not fair!
answer: What kind of life is it to be pitied and stared at?

question: What kind of life is it to be hidden away? I know you believe that what you are suggesting for Franklin is best. But I think you are making it harder for him.
answer: I think I know what's best for Franklin. I am his mother!

question: Leave me here. Let the ocean swallow me up. Burial at sea. Perfect for a navy man. Louis?
answer: I never miss Florida in the rainy season.

question: No letter? No wire?
answer: Why? Would you have answered it?

question: What the hell are you doing here?
answer: Good to see you too. Nice whiskers. You look like Chester Arthur.

question: Stanley, this is Mr. Howe. He gets sea-sick at the mere sight of a boat so he's probably happy that it's being Ldestroyed right now. You're always so generous with my money.
answer: You mean your mother's, don't you?

question: So Mama financed this fool's errand, has she? Well, it's a waste of a trip.
answer: It was Eleanor's idea. I'd like some ham and eggs, sunny side up, please? What's your fancy, boss?

question: Nothing. I fancy nothing.
answer: He'll have the same. There are a few from your children.

question: I can still read.
answer: Your wife wants you to come home. She's concerned. I'm concerned. This life on a boat... where is it getting you?

question: Getting me? For one thing, no one gets to see me and I don't get to see them.
answer: Don't say that. Everyone's waiting for you to come home. The kids... they're aching to see you.

question: And I'm sick of home. Where's the letter from Peabody?
answer: You can't be serious?

question: Why not miracle waters? I've drunk the oil of monkey glands, been zapped with electricity and hung upside down in harnesses. After all that, this sounds downright peaceful.
answer: I can't quite picture you in the back woods of Georgia.

question: Where do you picture me, Louis?
answer: 1600 Pennsylvania Avenue.

question: President, Louis? I can't visit the bathroom without a team of associates to help pull my pants down.
answer: Give it a little time.

question: Someone important?
answer: You might say so, Lionel.

question: Who?
answer: A Mr. Roosevelt.

question: Teddy?
answer: No, he's dead.

question: Oh.
answer: Go over to the livery stable...

question: Hello! Hello! Mr. Loyless?
answer: Tom, Mr. Roosevelt.

question: Then you'd better call me Franklin.
answer: Franklin.

question: This is simply revolting.
answer: It's not very good, but it is mysterious. What in the world do you think they've poured over this chicken? Or is it possum?

question: You want to stay.
answer: Yes.

question: This isn't about getting better is it? You don't want to come home. You don't want to live with us.
answer: I refuse to be a burden to anyone.

question: You're not a burden, you're my husband.
answer: I want to offer you the freedom you once so generously offered me. All you've ever known is duty. To me and to a political career that unless I can walk no longer exists. You've been exemplary. Now I'm telling you you're free to go.

question: No. I don't want freedom. I want a marriage. I want a life with you.
answer: I can't imagine what you think that life is going to be.

question: To your mineral pool, or whatever you call it.
answer: Warm Springs.

question: Too strong?
answer: Haven't been in a drinking mood lately.

question: I have.
answer: Actually, its the most god-awful martini I've ever tasted.

question: Are you always this direct, Tom?
answer: Well, I never tasted a martini this bad before.

question: Everyone likes my martinis...
answer: So they say.

question: Tell me more about what that boy did, Aunt Sally.
answer: Well, first he'd always swim over to the side of the pool and hold himself there -- make sure he righted himself. Then... before he knew it... he'd be standing.

question: If it was only that easy.
answer: Well, you make it hard. Get over to the side of that pool and grab it.

question: Yes, ma'am.
answer: Now you got to remember how you did it.

question: Evening folks.
answer: Cocktail, Lionel?

question: I can't. I'm working for the federal government.
answer: All the more reason. Sort of late for the mail, isn't it?

question: Not for me it isn't. Got a whole packet of clippings for you, Mr. Roosevelt. From a Mr. Howe. New York Times, Journal-American... don't know what else. Your mother wants to know when you're coming home. She says they got swimming pools in Hyde Park. She's mad as all hell.
answer: Reading other people's mail is not only impolite, it's illegal.

question: Sheriff don't mind. He likes I read his mail. Saves him the time. Plus a lot of folks around here can't read, so it's more a public service, really.
answer: Astonishing. Thank you, Lionel.

question: Small town -- word gets out. It probably won't amount to more than a provincial puff piece but it might give us some free publicity for the Inn. All right, I know the gentleman. I'm doing him a favor. You know, I used to be a journalist.
answer: Do you mean all this time I've been talking to a newspaper man?

question: Not anymore. I got in a bit of trouble in Atlanta. Seems some of the editorial pieces I wrote offended the sensibilities of a local civic group. So I needed to lay low for a while.
answer: You mean the Klan? Good God, Tom... Well, that explains a few things. For the life of me, I couldn't figure out why someone like you was running this --

question: Rat-trap?
answer: I was going to say dump, but rat- trap fits nicely.

question: I was going to say dump, but rat- trap fits nicely.
answer: Now in 1920 when you were running for Vice-President...

question: I can't imagine your readers are interested in ancient history. Cox and I lost the election by a wide margin.
answer: It was only a few years ago, Mr. Roosevelt...

question: Now it's the waters extra minerals plus its warmth that makes all the difference. At 90 degrees I can work my muscles for hours and not get cold.
answer: As Assistant Secretary of the Navy during the Great War did you condone the use of...

question: I forgot one more thing you will need to write down. Poor circulation is a chronic problem for people in my condition.
answer: So... you think it could be a cure?

question: I don't know.
answer: But you're hopeful?

question: Thank you, Missy, and c.c. that to Louis.
answer: Hungry, Mr. Roosevelt?

question: Not really.
answer: Who do you write to every morning?

question: Different people I knew in politics. Just in case they ever want me back.
answer: So you'll be ready when you get your legs workin' again?

question: Exactly.
answer: Excuse me, are you Mr. Roosevelt?

question: Yes. Who are you?
answer: My name is Benjamin Prendergast. I've come to see if you could speak at this year's graduation ceremony at the schoolhouse. You being so famous and all.

question: I'll be damned.
answer: Would you be available?

question: When? Next spring?
answer: Next week. We only have a four month school year.

question: How is that possible?
answer: Tax dollars only cover that much.

question: Are you graduating?
answer: No, sir. I'm the principal.

question: I see.
answer: Now that we're all here let me introduce to you to our guest speaker today, Mr. Franklin Roosevelt.

question: You wonder why I want to go back to Georgia... it's to avoid people who look at me the way you just did.
answer: You truly believe the waters... ... that they are helping?

question: Don't talk to me as if I were a child. Choosing your words so carefully...
answer: How am I supposed to talk to you?

question: Like I was! Talk to me like I was!
answer: I don't know how anymore.

question: We missed you at the station... Tom, are you all right?
answer: It's just an ulcer. I can't eat anything I like anymore.

question: My father had ulcers. Damn irritating.
answer: Yes, they are. Ready to swim? We've got some new guests. Some paying, some non-paying...

question: What in blazes?...
answer: The interview you gave was syndicated in Sunday papers all over the country. They're here to see you.

question: This isn't your personal spa! I have a business to run.
answer: Exactly. You have a business to run, not I!

question: No one's asking anything of you!
answer: Of course they are!

question: Do you know what it took for most of them to get here?
answer: It's not my concern. I want to be left alone!

question: My God, you're afraid of these people.
answer: Afraid? What you're talking about?

question: You look at them with the same repulsion and pity as everyone else.
answer: Don't be ridiculous. I resent your trying to --

question: You don't want to be around them because then that would make you one of them, wouldn't it?
answer: God damn it! Out of my way! Get out of my goddamn way!

question: Son, can you hear me? Fred?
answer: Mr. Roosevelt?...

question: It's going to be all right, son.
answer: The conductor wouldn't let me ride in the passenger car with my chair.

question: When did you last eat?
answer: Knoxville.

question: Roy, take him to the car. Who in their right mind let's a child ride in the baggage car! You could have killed that boy.
answer: He had polio. Probably still contagious.

question: Don't dismiss me because I sit in this chair!
answer: Get away from me.

question: Let's go home. How many can pay?
answer: Fewer than half.

question: I want these people in the cottages, not in the inn. It's safer.
answer: Well, it's the way it has to be.

question: What do you mean?
answer: I've already had some complaints. This is the start of the season, Franklin. I've got regulars who have come for years. Healthy folks over all... They're threatening to check out, afraid they might catch polio.

question: Such ignorance! Don't they know that after the fever breaks we are no longer contagious?
answer: I'm going to have to ask that you not use the pool during regular hours. I'll put time aside for you late in the day... and it won't be possible for you to eat in the dining room either. But I promise I'll find someplace suitable.

question: They don't want us to eat in their presence?
answer: Of course for you I can make other accommodations.

question: That won't be necessary.
answer: Thank you.

question: We still need a doctor here.
answer: For Fred?

question: For everyone. "Dear Babs, Things are very different upon my return." I am taking on responsibilities which none of my schooling in the spheres of higher learning or politics could have prepared me for... I have seen the casualties of war. But I have never seen this, a suffering so insidious, so silent, that it rattles my soul."
answer: When can I swim?

question: Soon. When you're a little stronger.
answer: When I'm asleep, in my dreams, I can still walk.

question: Me too. How long has it been... since you walked?
answer: Nine years. I'd just learned to ride a bike. After I got sick my mom was sure that the bike had caused it.

question: Did she sell it?
answer: No. She took it out back and shot it.

question: Jake Perrini, Bronx, New York.
answer: Roy, sir.

question: How you doin'? C'mon -- I won't bite.
answer: Mighty fine, sir. Mighty fine.

question: Doc? I'm sorry, you're Franklin Roosevelt, aren't you?
answer: Depends. Are you a lawyer?

question: No.
answer: Then Roosevelt it is. Wait!

question: I'm Helena Mahoney. I'm a physical therapist. You have no idea who I am, do you?
answer: Should I?

question: I wrote you a letter right after I saw the article in the paper. Didn't you read it?
answer: It got read, I assure you. But probably not by me.

question: I've been studying the effects of moist heat on polio patients and I think with repeated exercise in warm water...
answer: It can help them regain lost strength.

question: Yes.
answer: Incredibly I've come to the same conclusion myself.

question: I feel like I was brought here under false pretenses.
answer: Join the club.

question: Push against my hand.
answer: Give me the good news first.

question: Your gluteus maximus is better than I hoped. It will serve you well.
answer: Must be all that sitting.

question: I'm serious. Your right leg has some movement along the thigh. That's good because we can use it to help extend your hip, flex your knee and rotate your tibia.
answer: I'm supposed to walk on one side?

question: The water may help build some strength I'm not able to see yet. But to do that you would need to swim in the water much of the day. Not the limited hours you have now. a beat) Why should this place cater to a few able-bodied folk when it could be opened year round with polios?
answer: There's a need for a place like this, Tom.

question: There's a need for a place like this, Tom.
answer: Sounds like you've been reading up.

question: I wish there was more to read. Damn few things being written about any of this. To think of someone like Fred... locked away... his mind and heart so vibrant...
answer: It's a waste. An awful waste.

question: What's the acreage here?
answer: Roughly twelve hundred or so. Why?

question: I want to buy it. I think it would make one hell of an investment.
answer: Investment?

question: Twelve hundred acres? Enough for two resorts, don't you think?
answer: It would take money. There's a lot of land, rebuilding the inn, adding ramps and so many people can't pay...

question: Do you think old Peabody will sell?
answer: He'll sell.

question: How can you be so sure?
answer: Have you taken a look at this place?

question: Take it. I was bluffing.
answer: Very well. Gentlemen, the game is Five Card Stud, sevens are wild. Sevens are wild and you can all go to Hell! Where do you think you're going?

question: Going to Asheville to see my parents.
answer: I can't do this without you... we're only just beginning.

question: You. I've got cancer, Franklin. It's spread everywhere.
answer: I... I'll take you to the best doctors. We'll go to Atlanta right now --

question: He wants to use his entire trust fund to buy that... leper colony!
answer: Franklin has invited Louis and me to see the work he's been doing.

question: Work! Playing in a pool all day long? Squandering his birthright on a group of fawning strangers? I consider this your fault, Eleanor!
answer: I beg your pardon, Mama?

question: You have indulged him and this is the result.
answer: Indulged him? I have indulged him? He's a grown man who makes his own decisions.

question: But he does not need to buy it.
answer: If it's of any comfort to you, I agree.

question: Morning, Mr. Roosevelt.
answer: Peter, what are you doing with Tom's car?

question: I was as sorry as anyone to hear about Mr. Loyless's passing. Wished he coulda' lived to see this!
answer: What are you talking about?

question: Mr. Loyless had me come up and fetch this right after he brung it to Asheville. "Pete, he said, "Take this home and fix it up for Mr. Roosevelt."
answer: Pete... I can't drive a car.

question: You can now. Get on in and I'll teach ya'! That one there is your brake.
answer: Got it.

question: And there are other costs to consider.
answer: Mama will see that the children are provided for.

question: I'm not speaking of money.
answer: I have found something here which makes waking up in the morning remotely bearable and the two of you stand there...

question: Franklin, I need for you to be practical and realistic.
answer: Practical? I am trapped inside a body that no longer moves of my own volition. I am trying to be practical. Now either you're with me or against me. In or out!

question: I don't care for ultimatums disguised as debate.
answer: Where are you going? Eleanor! Get back here.

question: You can't talk to her like that.
answer: Oh really? Are you an expert on this now? How should I speak to my wife, Louis?

question: With the respect she deserves. Look, I don't deny the work you're doing here could be important --
answer: Could be?

question: The issue is whether you want to run a rehabilitation center or whether you want to run for office again.
answer: When I can walk, I'll run. This is a very special night we're celebrating. At last we are together eating in this dining room! Now please join me in welcoming Miss Jackie Mills, a new arrival along with her father, Samuel, all the way from Oakland, California. Let us also take this opportunity to welcome our two able-bodied guests, Mr. Louis Howe and my better half, Mrs. Franklin Roosevelt. Now for the musical portion of our program...

question: Let me. What is your most pressing concern?
answer: Getting a doctor to live on the premises full-time. Someone who, at the very least, could monitor our progress. Make us legitimate.

question: And that costs more money.
answer: Yes. But the real problem is no one is interested. The annual Orthopedics Convention is being held in Atlanta this weekend and I offered to speak. They turned me down flat.

question: A few weeks ago, the conditions at a garment factory on West 27th Street were brought to my attention. The owners claimed everything was satisfactory, but would never let anyone in to conduct a proper inspection. It took awhile, but we finally got in.
answer: We?

question: I showed up with someone from the Labor Board and we refused to leave until they let us in.
answer: What are you suggesting?

question: The sooner the better.
answer: What is it?

question: Who are you?
answer: I don't know how to drive.

question: I'll teach you.
answer: I'll break the news to Mama. I think it's going to be fun.

question: Babs... words fail me.
answer: You? Franklin Roosevelt? I do so love you.

question: It is. How's the Boll Weevil situation?
answer: Why do I get the feeling we're not smiling about the same thing?

question: Any good news?
answer: Creditors are gettin' cranky.

question: The operative word was good.
answer: Oh, yah, almost forgot. The doctor that came and studied ya'll sent his report. Save me the stamps?

question: It's not as bad as you think.
answer: Read it. Out loud. Page twenty-nine.

question: I already...
answer: Read it!

question: "Of the twenty three patients examined only one, a forty-four year old male, showed little visible signs of improvement..." This is one doctor's opinion, Franklin.
answer: Keep reading.

question: "There is marked falling away of the muscle masses on either side of the spine in the lower lumbar region. His lower extremities present a most depressing picture." "I feel after studying him that the psychological factor in his management is paramount. He has such courage and ambition. Yet at the same time he is such an extraordinarily sensitive emotional mechanism...
answer: Please.

question: ... that it will take all the skill which we can muster to lead him successfully to a recognition of his severe physical limitations without crushing him."
answer: Patronizing son-of-a-bitch! I wanted to walk again.

question: And you still might. This report legitimizes we've worked so hard for. We can raise funs now. It could change everything!
answer: It won't change anything for me.

question: Franklin, I won't play this game. I won't feel sorry for you. I met a boy today, ten years old. He's paralyzed from the waist down. Why don't you go regale him with vivid tales about your trips to Europe and playing football at school. Tell him how you courted your wife and fathered children. Tell him of a life he can only dream of. I can't help you out of a hole if I climb in with you. Then we're both stuck.
answer: Here's another one he's refusin'.

question: Why don't you read it?
answer: Don't like telegrams. All them STOPS and stuff.

question: Make you dizzy, Lionel.
answer: A little bit.

question: Hello, Roy. I can't believe you've made me come all the way back to this hell hole!
answer: I've done no such thing.

question: I'm here to take you to Houston. You started your speech yet?
answer: I'm not going.

question: You know what this is, don't you? It's a golden opportunity. A springboard for you to run for Governor. Ever hear of a Civil War General named Francis Nicholls?
answer: No.

question: Well, I never heard of him either. But this was one brave son-of-a- bitch. Fought for the Confederacy and lost his left arm in one battle and his left foot in another. Then after the war he ran and won the Governorship of Louisiana -- twice!
answer: He was a war hero.

question: Twice. Look, I've worked like a dog to keep your name in play, grovelling at the feet of the powers-that-be in back rooms.
answer: As much for you as for me.

question: You're a mess.
answer: The report. I'll never...

question: Oh my darling...
answer: I'm useless, Eleanor. I feel so useless.

question: Franklin, let go of your crutches. You're not going to need them.
answer: What?

question: We're going to make your arms function as your legs.
answer: How is that possible?

question: I'm fine. I'm just...
answer: This isn't a replacement for the real work we're doing to get you on your feet again, understand? No one is throwing in the towel or even agreeing with that doctor's report...

question: I know, I know.
answer: I know it's not practical --

question: Why is he working so hard to hide it?
answer: He doesn't have a choice.

question: Oh, I disagree.
answer: How can you disagree? "There but for the grace of God goes us," that's what they're saying. As if our bodies is who we are, but it's not. It's our souls is who we are, but they don't know that.

question: And so America must find... No, America needs a pathfinder...
answer: That's good.

question: To emblaze the trail along a high road that will avoid... avoid the bottomless morass...
answer: What is it? What's wrong?

question: What if I fall... trying to get to the podium.
answer: If you fall, you show them how to get up.

question: No, if I fall in front of thousands of people I lose everything but their pity. They'll be writing my obituary before I get up off the floor.
answer: Elliot won't let you fall, he'll be there. All the arrangements have been made, boss. It'll be fine.

question: It's beautiful.
answer: Don't wear it in the pool.

question: I'll try not to. Good luck, Franklin.
answer: I'm throwing myself to the wolves.

question: You've faced worse. And if they bite, you can come back here.
answer: I'll always come back here. You're being superstitious, Louis. There aren't any reporters here. Thank you.
